channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: An Online Shift in China Muffles an Open Forum
item.description: A turn from the microblogging service Sina Weibo to the Facebook-like WeChat has reoriented the nation’s social media landscape from public to semiprivate communication.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: In recent months, Weibo has been eclipsed by WeChat, which allows instant messaging within self-selected circles of followers.

item.title: Emilio Álvarez Montalván, Nicaragua’s Pro-Democracy Sage, Dies at 94
item.description: Dr. Álvarez was an ophthalmologist, former guerrilla, political prisoner, diplomat and trenchant critic of dictatorship, was often called the wisest man in Nicaragua.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN KINZER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Police Make More Arrests in Huge Hong Kong Protest
item.description: Protest leaders say the police are trying to stifle dissent by carrying out arrests as pro-democracy groups plan more demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Chinese Leader, Underlining Ties to South Korea, Cites Japan as Onetime Mutual Enemy
item.description: President Xi Jinping reminded South Koreans on Friday that their two countries had fought “shoulder to shoulder” against Japan more than four centuries ago.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China speaking in Seoul, South Korea, on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Tycoon Pays Homage to a Fading Martyr
item.description: Chen Guangbiao draws the media spotlight again by paying respects at the grave of Lei Feng, the People’s Liberation Army martyr.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and MIA LI
item.media:description: The Chinese tycoon Chen Guangbiao visiting the grave of Lei Feng, a martyr of the People's Liberation Army.

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: Refugee Camp for Syrians in Jordan Evolves as a Do-It-Yourself City
item.description: As the sprawling Zaatari camp evolves into an informal city — with an economy and even gentrification — aid workers say camps can be potential urban incubators that benefit host countries like Jordan.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The main market of the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan. Displaced Syrians there have a travel agency and even pizza delivery.

item.title: World Cup 2014: Argentina Fans Hope to Spoil Brazil's Tournament
item.description: Tens of thousands of Argentines have traveled to Brazil, stirring worries among Brazilians about violence and about Argentina winning the World Cup.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID WALDSTEIN
item.media:description: Argentine fans, celebrating their team’s victory Tuesday, have been willing to visit coastal cities, but fewer of them are considered likely to travel to Brasilia.

item.title: Poised to Gain in Iraq Crisis, Kurds Face New Barriers to Autonomy
item.description: Although exporting its vast oil supply would give the Kurdish government leverage in its push for sovereignty, opposition from other nations has left the region’s future uncertain.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: World Briefing: India: Prime Minister Visits Kashmir
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday made his first official trip to Indian-controlled Kashmir, where separatist groups called a strike that shut shops, businesses and schools.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Honduras: Search for Miners Continues
item.description: Eight miners remained missing after three others were rescued Friday after more than two days trapped underground in a small wildcat gold mine that collapsed in southern Honduras.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: At Least 6 Die After Saudi Border Post Is Attacked
item.description: A suicide bomber and two security officers were among those killed at a Saudi-Yemeni border crossing on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: Troops in Deadly Clash With Separatists
item.description: Fighting in eastern Ukraine left at least nine Ukrainian soldiers dead and 13 wounded on Friday, Ukrainian officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Enraged Soldiers Riot in Lagos
item.description: Soldiers blocked roads, fired shots into the air and burned several buses on Friday after a fellow soldier was killed in a bus accident, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: 2 Ex-Military Officers Sentenced in Death of Bishop
item.description: The former senior military officers received life in prison on Friday for the death of Bishop Enrique Angelelli in 1976.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Preschool Teacher Is Stabbed to Death in Classroom in France
item.description: The police said the suspect, the mother of a pupil in the teacher’s class, had been in treatment for “serious psychiatric problems.”
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Saturday Profile: The Rev. Tomas Halik Castigates Putin for Russia’s Seizure of Crimea
item.description: The Rev. Tomas Halik, a leading intellectual in the Czech Republic, an ally of Vaclav Havel’s and an outspoken critic, has turned his attention to the Ukraine crisis, denouncing President Vladimir V. Putin as a “war criminal” for Russia’s seizure of Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Milan Bures for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I am a main target because I am so visible. But I don’t think I am so progressive a Catholic. At bottom, I have very moderate beliefs,” says the Rev. Tomas Halik, who was ordained in the underground church of the Czech Republic.

item.title: World Cup 2014: Ángel di María Emerges as a Threat for Argentina
item.description: Ángel di María of Argentina, who comes from the same town as Lionel Messi, has excelled at the World Cup and has monopolized the front pages back home.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: Ángel di María after scoring the winning goal against Switzerland in the Round of 16.

item.title: Iraqi Premier to Run for a Third Term
item.description: Despite nearly universal criticism in Iraq, and pressure from friendly nations to step down, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki announced, “I will not give up my candidacy.”
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the Sadr City neighborhood of Baghdad on Friday, a television in a shop was tuned to a religious service as Shiite men waited outside for the beginning of their weekly Muslim prayers.

item.title: German Man Arrested as Spy Implicates U.S.
item.description: German news media reported that the man, 31, worked for Germany’s intelligence service and was suspected of spying for the United States.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Google Reinstates European Links to Articles From The Guardian
item.description: As the search engine restores links that it had removed to comply with a court order, its handling of the “right to be forgotten” becomes murkier.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT

item.title: It’s Tasty and Political: Britain Presses U.S. on Haggis
item.description: With a Scottish vote on independence two months away, Britain is lobbying America to allow imports of the delicacy made from sheep’s innards, which the United States banned for consumption in 1971.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Haggis to go, but not to the United States.

item.title: German Proposal Seeks to Sharply Curtail Fracking
item.description: The energy and environment ministers seek to ban shale gas and oil drilling for commercial purposes.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Italy Accuses Germany of Undermining Its Economic Efforts
item.description: The Italian prime minister responded to criticism by the head of the Bundesbank that Italy needed to push harder for economic reforms.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Matteo Renzi, Italy’s prime minister, in Rome on Friday before a meeting with José Manuel Barroso, the departing president of the European Commission.

item.title: Tensions High in Jerusalem as Palestinian Teenager Is Given a Martyr’s Burial
item.description: The funeral for Muhammad Hussein Abu Khdeir, widely presumed to have been killed in an act of retaliation, was seen as a potential flash point.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners carried the body of Muhammad Abu Khdeir, covered with a Palestinian flag, during a funeral ceremony on Friday.

item.title: Rolf Harris Gets 5 Years and 9 Months for Assaulting Girls and Women
item.description: Rolf Harris, 84, once one of Britain’s most popular television hosts, was convicted of assaulting four girls and young women.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Rolf Harris, 84, was sentenced to prison for assaults decades ago on victims ages 8 to 19, including his daughter’s friend.
